\title{Math 320 HW 2}
\date{Due: Jan. 31, 2023 at 11:59 PM}
\maketitle

\section*{1)}

None of these sets with binary operation are groups. Each of these
almost groups fails at least one of the group axioms. For each of
these almost groups, show which axioms fail and which axioms hold.
\begin{enumerate}
\item $\mathbb{Z}$ under $\diamond$, where $a\diamond b=\left|a-b\right|$
\item $\mathcal{F}\left(\mathbb{R},\mathbb{R}\right)$ under $\circ$, where
$\mathcal{F}\left(\mathbb{R},\mathbb{R}\right)=\left\{ f:\mathbb{R}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}\right\} $
and $\left(f\circ g\right)\left(x\right)=f\left(g\left(x\right)\right)$ 
\end{enumerate}

\section*{2)}

The group of invertible $n\times n$ real matrices under matrix multiplication
is called The General Linear Group over $\mathbb{R}$ and denoted
as $GL_{n}\left(\mathbb{R}\right)$. Show 

\subsection*{a)}

$GL_{n}\left(\mathbb{R}\right)$ is a group (Hint: For $n\times n$
matrices $A,B$, $\det\left(AB\right)=\det\left(A\right)\det\left(B\right)$)

\subsection*{b)}

The set of $n\times n$ invertible matrices does not form a group
under matrix addition.

\section*{3)}

The shoe-sock property states for all $a,b\in G$, that 

\[
\left(ab\right)^{-1}=b^{-1}a^{-1}
\]


\subsection*{a)}

Prove the shoe-sock property

\subsection*{b)}

This can be generalized to the following:

\[
\left(a_{1}a_{2}\dots a_{n}\right)^{-1}=a_{n}^{-1}a_{n-1}^{-1}\dots a_{2}^{-1}a_{1}^{-1}
\]

Prove this.

\section*{4)}

Determine if the set $H$ is a subgroup of the given group $G$ under
the same binary operation as $G$. If so, prove it. Otherwise, explain
why it isn't.
\begin{enumerate}
\item $H=\left\{ 3n|n\in\mathbb{Z}\right\} $, $G=\left(\mathbb{Z},+\right)$
\item $H=\left\{ 1,2,5\right\} ,$$G=\left(Z_{6},+\right)$
\item $H=\left\{ \left(\begin{array}{cc}
a & b\\
c & d
\end{array}\right)|a,b,c,d\in\mathbb{Z}\right\} $, $G=\left(\left\{ \mathbb{R}^{2\times2}\right\} ,+\right)$
\end{enumerate}

\section*{5)}

Prove that a group $G$ is abelian if and only if $\left(ab\right)^{-1}=a^{-1}b^{-1}\ \forall a,b\in G$.

\section*{6)}

Consider the cyclic group $\mathbb{Z}_{6}$. 

\subsection*{a)}

Find all of the subgroups of $\mathbb{Z}_{6}$

\subsection*{b)}

Draw multiplication tables for each of these subgroups and color each
element in the table a distinct color. Remember, even though this
is a multiplication table, the binary operation is addition mod $6$.

\subsection*{c)}

What patterns do you notice in these multiplication tables?

\section*{7)}

Solve the following equations for $x$ in the given cyclic group.
If multiple solutions exist, be sure to state all solutions.

\subsection*{a)}

$x+4+1\equiv_{11}7$, $G=\mathbb{Z}_{11}$

\subsection*{b)}

$3*x\equiv_{13}1$, $G=U\left(13\right)$

\subsection*{c)}

$2*x\equiv_{11}3$, $G=U\left(11\right)$
